newsitem.title: UK: INSIGHT -FTSE TO RETREAT TO THE 4,950-4,970 REGION.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT -FTSE TO RETREAT TO THE 4,950-4,970 REGION.

text.p: The FTSE 100 index will retreat to the 4,950-4,970 region on Monday having lost all ambitions to break into record ground last week, technical analysts said.
Interest rate sensitive stocks including the banks and utilities will suffer today's downturn, they added.
The market's swift about-turn on Friday will ensure selling pressure continues as those who were slow off the mark on Friday will clamber to take profits.
"It will be a case of selling on rallies," said one analyst, adding that fear of inflationary pressure in the U.S. leading to higher interest rates over there will send UK stocks lower.

"The nearest chart support (for the FTSE) is at 4,950-4,970," said the analyst who based his forecast from a an inspection of a daily bar chart of the index and its 10-day moving average -- the latter being at 4,960.
The U.S. long bond fell below chart support at $101-28, taking the yield up to over 6.6 percent and which caused the fallout in the UK and U.S. on Friday.

Analysts predict the yield could go anywhere between 6.75-7.75 percent short-term which will put pressure on equities as the market awaits inflation reports from the U.S. in the form of producer prices on Wednesday and consumer prices on Thursday.
"If this data shows U.S. inflation is on the march, equities on both sides of the Atlantic will take a dive," said one analyst.
By 0744 GMT, the FTSE was down 53.8 to 4,977.5.
